verses.text: We who are strong ought to bear with the weaknesses of those who are not strong, and not to please ourselves.
verses.comment: Paul encourages mutual support within the Church. This reflects the importance of self-sacrifice and serving others, a theme deeply rooted in Jesus’ teaching (cf. Matt. 20:28).

verses.text: Let each of us please his neighbor for his good, to build him up.
verses.comment: The call to edify others underlines the communal nature of the faith—believers are responsible for one another’s spiritual growth.

verses.text: For even Christ did not please Himself, but as it is written: ‘The insults of those who insulted you fell on Me.’
verses.comment: Paul quotes Psalm 69, showing how Christ perfectly exemplifies self-denial for the sake of others. This points to Christ’s fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy and hints at the sacrificial nature of Christian leadership.

verses.text: For whatever was written in former times was written for our instruction, so that through endurance and the encouragement of the Scriptures we might have hope.
verses.comment: Paul affirms the enduring authority and relevance of Scripture for believers. Both Old and New Testament writings are meant for the building up of the Church, underscoring the necessity of Scriptural tradition.

verses.text: May the God of endurance and encouragement grant you to live in harmony with one another, in keeping with Christ Jesus.
verses.comment: Unity in the Church mirrors the unity between Christ and His followers. The spiritual sense here is of communal grace and alignment with Christ’s will.

verses.text: So that together you may glorify the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ with one voice.
verses.comment: Paul envisions a Church united in worship and doctrine. Togetherness in praise is both a spiritual and visible sign of Christian communion and identity.

verses.text: Therefore receive one another as Christ also received you, to the glory of God.
verses.comment: Reception of one another reflects the welcoming nature of the Body of Christ. This has both literal implications for community and spiritual for the full embrace of all God’s people.

verses.text: For I say that Christ became a servant to the circumcised, to show God’s truthfulness, in order to confirm the promises given to the patriarchs.
verses.comment: Paul highlights Jesus’ mission first to the Jews, showing the continuity between Old Testament covenant promises and their fulfillment in Christ.

verses.text: And that the Gentiles might glorify God for His mercy, as it is written: ‘Therefore I will praise you among the nations, and sing to your name.’
verses.comment: Paul reveals the inclusion of Gentiles as part of the divine plan foretold in Scripture. The universal scope of salvation is a key theme in God’s redemptive work.

verses.text: Again it says, ‘Rejoice, O Gentiles, with His people.’
verses.comment: Old Testament prophecy foretold the joining of the Gentiles with the people of God, a theme now fulfilled in the Church’s universal nature.

verses.text: And again, ‘Praise the Lord, all nations; let all peoples praise Him.’
verses.comment: This calls all humanity into worship of God. The literal meaning is universal praise; the spiritual sense is unity of all peoples in one faith.

verses.text: And again, Isaiah says, ‘The root of Jesse will come, even He who rises to rule the Gentiles; in Him the Gentiles will hope.’
verses.comment: Old Testament prophecy points to Christ as the ruler and hope for all nations. The high christology here affirms the Messiah’s divine authority over Jew and Gentile alike.

verses.text: May the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace in believing, so that by the power of the Holy Spirit you may abound in hope.
verses.comment: Paul places emphasis on the work of the Holy Spirit in the believer’s life, showing the necessity of grace for enduring hope.

verses.text: I myself am convinced about you, my brothers, that you are full of goodness, filled with all knowledge, and able to instruct one another.
verses.comment: Paul acknowledges the spiritual maturity and wisdom among the believers, encouraging the practice of fraternal correction and teaching within the Church.

verses.text: But I have written to you more boldly on some points, to remind you, because of the grace that was given to me by God.
verses.comment: Paul refers to his apostolic authority, established by divine grace, which communicates God’s will authoritatively.

verses.text: To be a servant of Christ Jesus to the Gentiles, ministering as a priest the gospel of God, so that the offering of the Gentiles may be acceptable, sanctified by the Holy Spirit.
verses.comment: Paul uses priestly language, associating apostolic work with sacrificial service. The notion of spiritual offering and sanctification highlights the continuation of sacred tradition in ministerial roles.

verses.text: In Christ Jesus, then, I have reason to glory in things pertaining to God.
verses.comment: Paul claims all his ministry is founded upon Christ, who is the source of all glory and the subject of Christian boasting.

verses.text: For I will not dare to speak of anything except what Christ has accomplished through me to bring the Gentiles to obedience—by word and deed,
verses.comment: Paul recognizes that his achievements stem from Christ working through him, highlighting apostolic obedience.

verses.text: By the power of signs and wonders, by the power of the Spirit of God—so that from Jerusalem and all the way around to Illyricum I have fulfilled the ministry of the gospel of Christ.
verses.comment: Paul points to miracles and the Holy Spirit as confirmation of his mission, reflecting the continuing work of God through ordained ministers.

verses.text: And in this way I made it my aim to preach the gospel, not where Christ has already been named, lest I build on someone else’s foundation,
verses.comment: Paul distinguishes his unique apostolic calling to reach the unreached, respecting the foundation laid by others.

verses.text: But as it is written, ‘Those who were not told about Him will see, and those who have not heard will understand.’
verses.comment: Paul uses prophecy to describe the expansion of the gospel to all nations, reinforcing the Church’s mission to evangelize.

verses.text: This is why I have often been hindered from coming to you.
verses.comment: Paul’s ministry obligations delayed his visit, suggesting the importance of apostolic priorities and obedience to divine calling.

verses.text: But now, with no further room for work in these regions, and since I have desired for many years to come to you,
verses.comment: Paul’s sense of completion in his mission signals the strategic nature of his apostolic endeavors.

verses.text: I hope to see you as I go to Spain, and to be helped on my journey there by you, once I have enjoyed your company for a while.
verses.comment: Paul values fellowship and material support in his missionary work, connecting the practical with the spiritual duties of the Church.

verses.text: But now I am going to Jerusalem to serve the saints.
verses.comment: Paul maintains connection with the mother church in Jerusalem, honoring the importance of unity with the apostolic center.

verses.text: For Macedonia and Achaia were pleased to make some contribution for the poor among the saints at Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Charitable giving links the various local churches in spiritual solidarity with Jerusalem, furthering the unity of the Church.

verses.text: They were pleased to do it, and indeed they owe it to them. For if the Gentiles have shared in their spiritual blessings, they ought also to serve them in material things.
verses.comment: Material support for those at Jerusalem reflects the interdependence of the whole Church. The literal sense is financial, but spiritually it demonstrates familial bonds.

verses.text: When therefore I have completed this and have delivered to them what has been collected, I will leave for Spain by way of you.
verses.comment: Paul outlines his journey as part of his broader mission, indicating the necessity of order and planning in gospel work.

verses.text: I know that when I come to you, I will come in the fullness of the blessing of Christ.
verses.comment: Fullness of blessing suggests an abundance of grace that flows through apostolic ministry and the Church’s unity.

verses.text: I appeal to you, brothers, by our Lord Jesus Christ and by the love of the Spirit, to strive together with me in prayers to God on my behalf,
verses.comment: Paul requests intercessory prayer, which is a means of communal participation in each other’s spiritual lives. This reflects shared responsibility for the body.

verses.text: That I may be delivered from those in Judea who are disobedient, and that my service for Jerusalem may be acceptable to the saints,
verses.comment: Paul emphasizes deliverance from opposition and approval from the Church’s leadership; both are essential for fruitful ministry.

verses.text: So that by God’s will I may come to you with joy and be refreshed together with you.
verses.comment: Paul’s intention to visit reflects the joy and spiritual renewal found in fellowship with the wider Church.

verses.text: May the God of peace be with you all. Amen.
verses.comment: Paul ends with a blessing invoking peace upon the Church, aligning with the biblical tradition of apostolic benediction.
